title: 111_s1819
content: The Act may be cited as the "International Civil Rights Center and Museum Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress acknowledges the significance of the Greensboro sit-in of 1960, which sparked nonviolent protests against segregation across the United States. Over 70,000 people participated in similar demonstrations by August 1961 in over 60 cities. This led to the establishment of the International Civil Rights Center and Museum. The International Civil Rights Center and Museum, located at the site of the F.W. Woolworth's store where the sit-in movement began, will serve as an archival center and teaching facility exploring the international struggle for civil and human rights. It will officially open on February 1, 2010, commemorating the 50th anniversary of the beginning of the sit-in movement. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue up to 1,000 $1 silver coins commemorating the opening of the International Civil Rights Center and Museum. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of coins for the International Civil Rights Center and Museum will include $1 silver coins weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The design of coins minted under this Act shall be emblematic of the International Civil Rights Center and Museum, with inscriptions including the coin's value, the year "2010", and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design of coins minted under this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the International Civil Rights Center and Museum and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at the United States Mint at West Point, New York. The Secretary is authorized to mint these coins only during the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2010. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at the United States Mint at West Point, New York. The Secretary is authorized to mint these coins only during the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2010. Sale of coins. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted before issuance. The coins minted under this Act will be sold at face value, surcharge, and design cost. Prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. The Act requires a $10 surcharge per coin sold, with proceeds going to the International Civil Rights Center and Museum for program development. The Comptroller General can audit the Museum's expenditures related to these funds.
